#Text=III
#Text=Oscar Maironi was very poor .
#Text=His thin gray suit in summer resembled his thick gray suit in winter .

#Text=It does not seem that he had more than two ; but he had a black coat and waistcoat , and a narrow-brimmed , shiny hat to go with these , and one pair of patent-leather shoes that laced , and whose long soles curved upward at the toe like the rockers of a summer-hotel chair .

#Text=These holiday garments served him in all seasons ; and when you saw him dressed in them , and seated in a car bound for Park Square , you knew he was going into Boston , where he would read manuscript essays on Botticelli or Pico della Mirandola , or manuscript translations of Armenian folksongs ; read these to ecstatic , dim-eyed ladies in Newbury Street , who would pour him cups of tea when it was over , and speak of his earnestness after he was gone .
#Text=It did not do the ladies any harm ; but I am not sure that it was the best thing for Oscar .

#Text=It helped him feel every day , as he stepped along to recitations with his elbow clamping his books against his ribs and his heavy black curls bulging down from his gray slouch hat to his collar , how meritorious he was compared with Bertie and Billy -- with all Berties and Billies .
#Text=He may have been .
#Text=Who shall say ?
#Text=But I will say at once that chewing the cud of one ’s own virtue gives a sour stomach .
#Text=Bertie ’s and Billy ’s parents owned town and country houses in New York .
#Text=The parents of Oscar had come over in the steerage .
#Text=Money filled the pockets of Bertie and Billy ; therefore were their heads empty of money and full of less cramping thoughts .
#Text=Oscar had fallen upon the reverse of this fate .
#Text=Calculation was his second nature .
#Text=He had given his education to himself ; he had for its sake toiled , traded , outwitted , and saved .

#Text=He had sent himself to college , where most of the hours not given to education and more education , went to toiling and more toiling , that he might pay his meagre way through the college world .
#Text=He had a cheaper room and ate cheaper meals than was necessary .
#Text=He tutored , and he wrote college specials for several newspapers .
#Text=His chief relaxation was the praise of the ladies in Newbury Street .
#Text=These told him of the future which awaited him , and when they gazed upon his features were put in mind of the dying Keats .
#Text=Not that Oscar was going to die in the least .
#Text=Life burned strong in him .
#Text=There were sly times when he took what he had saved by his cheap meals and room and went to Boston with it , and for a few hours thoroughly ceased being ascetic .
#Text=Yet Oscar felt meritorious when he considered Bertie and Billy ; for , like the socialists , merit with him meant not being able to live as well as your neighbor .
#Text=You will think that I have given to Oscar what is familiarly termed a black eye .
#Text=But I was once inclined to applaud his struggle for knowledge , until I studied him close and perceived that his love was not for the education he was getting .
#Text=Bertie and Billy loved play for play ’s own sake , and in play forgot themselves , like the wholesome young creatures that they were .
#Text=Oscar had one love only : through all his days whatever he might forget , he would remember himself ; through all his days he would make knowledge show that self off .
#Text=Thank heaven , all the poor students in Harvard College were not Oscars !
#Text=I loved some of them as much as I loved Bertie and Billy .
#Text=So there is no black eye about it .

#Text=Pity Oscar , if you like ; but do n’t be so mushy as to admire him as he stepped along in the night , holding his notes , full of his knowledge , thinking of Bertie and Billy , conscious of virtue , and smiling his smile .
#Text=They were not conscious of any virtue , were Bertie and Billy , nor were they smiling .
#Text=They were solemnly eating up together a box of handsome strawberries and sucking the juice from their reddened thumbs .
#Text=“ Rather mean not to make him wait and have some of these after his hard work on us , ” said Bertie .
#Text=“ I ’d forgotten about them -- ”
#Text=“ He ran out before you could remember , anyway , ” said Billy .
#Text=“ Was n’t he absurd about his old notes ? “
#Text=Bertie went on , a new strawberry in his mouth .
#Text=“ We do n’t need them , though .
#Text=With to-morrow
#Text=we ’ll get this course down cold . ”
#Text=“ Yes , to-morrow , ” sighed Billy .
#Text=“ It ’s awful to think of another day of this kind . ”
#Text=“ Horrible , ” assented Bertie .
#Text=“ He knows a lot .
#Text=He ’s extraordinary , ” said Billy .
#Text=“ Yes , he is .
#Text=He can talk the actual words of the notes .
#Text=Probably he could teach the course himself .
#Text=I do n’t suppose he buys any strawberries , even when they get ripe and cheap here .
#Text=What ’s the matter with you ? ”
#Text=Billy had broken suddenly into merriment .
#Text=“ I do n’t believe Oscar owns a bath , ” he explained .
#Text=“ By Jove !
#Text=so his notes will burn in spite of everything ! ”
#Text=And both of the tennis boys shrieked foolishly .

#Text=Then Billy began taking his clothes off , strewing them in the window-seat , or anywhere that they happened to drop ; and Bertie , after hitting another cork or two out of the window with the tennis racket , departed to his own room on another floor and left Billy to immediate and deep slumber .
#Text=This was broken for a few moments when Billy ’s room-mate returned happy from an excursion which had begun in the morning .
